Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Location Tracking, Contact Tracing and Geospatial Privacy in COVID-19

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Public health systems in the United States have the ability to conduct manual contact tracing; however they do not have the capacity to trace individuals at the scale needed to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic. Consequently, work is underway to develop contact tracing applications that use the mobile tracking technologies (e.g., GPS, Bluetooth) in personal devices to gather, store, and retrieve an individualâ€™s location and contact history. This project assesses the technological limits of mobile location tracking applications being used in COVID1-19 for contact tracing by public health officials to mitigate COVID-19. At the same time this research will address questions of geospatial privacy, including 1) notice-and-consent to location data collection, and 2) risk of personal identification. The project will provide data and results that are needed to develop more effective contact tracing systems. The databases and publications created by this research will contribute to an informed public debate about the role contact tracing should play during different phases of the pandemic.<br/><br/>As public health officials expand contact tracing systems in response to COVID-19, it is essential to know when and where those systems are likely to be most accurate. To meet these needs, this project will catalog and evaluate the contact tracking technologies as they are deployed and developed across the United States. Comparative studies across states will facilitate the identification of the technologies and practices that are most effective in different regional environments. More broadly, this research will fill the gap in geospatial privacy literature by addressing geospatial privacy of newly evolving mobile location tracking technologies and how these technologies can contribute to the health and welfare of sociey.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many public health authorities have adopted digital contact tracing technologies (DCTT) to combat the spread of the SARS-CoV-2 virus responsible for COVID-19. The central aim of this project was to better understand the privacy and ethical implications of these systems and their effectiveness in varied regional environments. To evaluate these contact tracing technologies as they were developed and deployed around the United States, the PI and a team of undergraduate and graduate students conducted an ongoing survey of state public health authorities between June 2020 and Jan 2021.

First, the PI developed and published a conceptual framework outlining the ethical and privacy issues linked to digital contact tracing technologies and their evaluation. This framework became the foundation of the project protocols and guided data collection. Data collected during 2020 revealed the slow adoption of these technologies throughout the United States as state authorities managing pandemic response often lacked the internal capacity and resources to develop and deploy these systems. The adoption of digital contact tracing technologies accelerated as a single technology platform emerged in the Fall of 2020. As individual digital contact tracing systems became publicly available in each state, the geospatial technologies used in each system and their privacy implications were assessed using the project's conceptual framework. The digital contact tracing technologies evaluated use anonymized and ephemeral contact records stored in a decentralized manner to preserve privacy.

Second, the project aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of digital contact tracing technologies in different state environments. A key finding is that, as presently deployed in the United States, these technologies do not collect much of the information needed to directly measure their impact on the spread of SARS-CoV-2, or how that effectiveness may vary across regional geographies. Difficulty in directly measuring the role digital contact tracing technologies play in breaking chains of transmission in different environments stems from the ways in which these systems are designed to preserve privacy. We linked the challenges of assessing the impact of these technologies and their effectiveness to different aspects of system configuration and to technical limitations This approach allowed us to consider how these systems could be adjusted to facilitate effectiveness assessments while still matching privacy goals.   

The protocols, instruments, data, and reports created during this project are available through a project website and associated online repositories. These materials can be used by others studying digital contact tracing technologies, or by those interested in altering the protocols of these systems so we might better evaluate their impact and effectiveness while still balancing privacy and ethical concerns. Seven undergraduate and one graduate students received training during this project.
